Stores

Stores provide fine-grained reactive state management for complex nested data structures.

Why Use Stores?

While signals work great for primitive values, stores excel at managing complex objects with nested reactivity:

  • Fine-grained updates to nested properties
  • Immutable update patterns
  • Path-based access and updates
  • Array and object manipulation helpers

createStore

1import { createStore } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [state, setState] = createStore({
4  user: {
5    name: 'Alice',
6    age: 30,
7    preferences: {
8      theme: 'dark',
9      notifications: true,
10    },
11  },
12  todos: [
13    { id: 1, text: 'Learn PhilJS', completed: false },
14    { id: 2, text: 'Build app', completed: false },
15  ],
16});
17 
18// Read values
19console.log(state.user.name); // 'Alice'
20console.log(state.todos[0].text); // 'Learn PhilJS'
i

Proxies

Stores use JavaScript Proxies to track property access and enable fine-grained reactivity.

Updating Stores

Simple Updates

1// Update top-level property
2setState('user', { name: 'Bob', age: 25, preferences: {...} });
3 
4// Update nested property
5setState('user', 'name', 'Bob');
6setState('user', 'age', 31);
7 
8// Update deeply nested
9setState('user', 'preferences', 'theme', 'light');

Function Updates

1// Update based on previous value
2setState('user', 'age', age => age + 1);
3 
4// Update with path
5setState('user', 'preferences', prefs => ({
6  ...prefs,
7  notifications: false,
8}));

Multiple Updates

1// Update multiple properties at once
2setState({
3  user: {
4    ...state.user,
5    name: 'Charlie',
6    age: 35,
7  },
8});
9 
10// Or using the produce pattern
11import { produce } from 'philjs-core';
12 
13setState(produce(draft => {
14  draft.user.name = 'Charlie';
15  draft.user.age = 35;
16  draft.todos.push({ id: 3, text: 'New todo', completed: false });
17}));

Array Updates

1const [state, setState] = createStore({
2  todos: [
3    { id: 1, text: 'First', completed: false },
4    { id: 2, text: 'Second', completed: true },
5  ],
6});
7 
8// Add item
9setState('todos', todos => [...todos, newTodo]);
10 
11// Remove item
12setState('todos', todos => todos.filter(t => t.id !== 1));
13 
14// Update specific item
15setState('todos', 0, 'completed', true);
16 
17// Update item by condition
18setState(
19  'todos',
20  todo => todo.id === 2,
21  'text',
22  'Updated text'
23);
24 
25// Batch array operations
26setState('todos', produce(todos => {
27  todos.push(newTodo);
28  todos[0].completed = true;
29  todos.sort((a, b) => a.id - b.id);
30}));

Reconcile for Immutable Updates

1import { reconcile } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Replace entire state while maintaining reactivity
4const newData = await fetchData();
5setState(reconcile(newData));
6 
7// Reconcile nested object
8setState('user', reconcile({
9  name: 'New Name',
10  age: 40,
11  preferences: { theme: 'dark', notifications: true },
12}));
i

Reconcile vs Replace

reconcile intelligently merges new data, only updating changed values. This preserves references and minimizes reactive updates.

Common Patterns

Global Store

1// store.ts
2import { createStore } from 'philjs-core';
3 
4interface AppState {
5  user: User | null;
6  theme: 'light' | 'dark';
7  notifications: Notification[];
8}
9 
10export const [appState, setAppState] = createStore<AppState>({
11  user: null,
12  theme: 'light',
13  notifications: [],
14});
15 
16// Actions
17export const actions = {
18  setUser(user: User | null) {
19    setAppState('user', user);
20  },
21 
22  toggleTheme() {
23    setAppState('theme', theme =>
24      theme === 'light' ? 'dark' : 'light'
25    );
26  },
27 
28  addNotification(notification: Notification) {
29    setAppState('notifications', notifications => [
30      ...notifications,
31      notification,
32    ]);
33  },
34 
35  clearNotifications() {
36    setAppState('notifications', []);
37  },
38};
39 
40// Usage
41import { appState, actions } from './store';
42 
43function App() {
44  return (
45    <div className={appState.theme}>
46      <Show when={appState.user}>
47        {user => <div>Welcome, {user.name}!</div>}
48      </Show>
49    </div>
50  );
51}

Store Context

1import { createContext, useContext } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3interface TodoStore {
4  todos: Todo[];
5  addTodo: (text: string) => void;
6  toggleTodo: (id: number) => void;
7  removeTodo: (id: number) => void;
8}
9 
10const TodoContext = createContext<TodoStore>();
11 
12export function TodoProvider(props: { children: JSX.Element }) {
13  const [state, setState] = createStore({
14    todos: [] as Todo[],
15  });
16 
17  const store: TodoStore = {
18    get todos() {
19      return state.todos;
20    },
21 
22    addTodo(text: string) {
23      const newTodo = {
24        id: Date.now(),
25        text,
26        completed: false,
27      };
28      setState('todos', todos => [...todos, newTodo]);
29    },
30 
31    toggleTodo(id: number) {
32      setState(
33        'todos',
34        todo => todo.id === id,
35        'completed',
36        completed => !completed
37      );
38    },
39 
40    removeTodo(id: number) {
41      setState('todos', todos => todos.filter(t => t.id !== id));
42    },
43  };
44 
45  return (
46    <TodoContext.Provider value={store}>
47      {props.children}
48    </TodoContext.Provider>
49  );
50}
51 
52export function useTodos() {
53  const context = useContext(TodoContext);
54  if (!context) throw new Error('TodoContext not found');
55  return context;
56}
57 
58// Usage
59function TodoList() {
60  const todos = useTodos();
61 
62  return (
63    <For each={todos.todos}>
64      {todo => (
65        <TodoItem
66          todo={todo}
67          onToggle={() => todos.toggleTodo(todo.id)}
68          onRemove={() => todos.removeTodo(todo.id)}
69        />
70      )}
71    </For>
72  );
73}

Form State

1function RegistrationForm() {
2  const [form, setForm] = createStore({
3    values: {
4      name: '',
5      email: '',
6      password: '',
7      confirmPassword: '',
8    },
9    errors: {
10      name: '',
11      email: '',
12      password: '',
13      confirmPassword: '',
14    },
15    touched: {
16      name: false,
17      email: false,
18      password: false,
19      confirmPassword: false,
20    },
21  });
22 
23  const handleChange = (field: string, value: string) => {
24    setForm('values', field, value);
25    setForm('touched', field, true);
26    validate(field, value);
27  };
28 
29  const validate = (field: string, value: string) => {
30    let error = '';
31 
32    switch (field) {
33      case 'name':
34        error = value.length < 2 ? 'Name too short' : '';
35        break;
36      case 'email':
37        error = !value.includes('@') ? 'Invalid email' : '';
38        break;
39      case 'password':
40        error = value.length < 8 ? 'Password too short' : '';
41        break;
42      case 'confirmPassword':
43        error = value !== form.values.password ? 'Passwords must match' : '';
44        break;
45    }
46 
47    setForm('errors', field, error);
48  };
49 
50  const handleSubmit = (e: Event) => {
51    e.preventDefault();
52    if (Object.values(form.errors).some(err => err)) {
53      return;
54    }
55    submitForm(form.values);
56  };
57 
58  return (
59    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit}>
60      <input
61        value={form.values.name}
62        onInput={e => handleChange('name', e.currentTarget.value)}
63      />
64      <Show when={form.touched.name && form.errors.name}>
65        <span className="error">{form.errors.name}</span>
66      </Show>
67      {/* Other fields... */}
68    </form>
69  );
70}

Memoized Selectors

1const [state, setState] = createStore({
2  todos: [] as Todo[],
3  filter: 'all' as 'all' | 'active' | 'completed',
4});
5 
6// Create memoized selectors
7const filteredTodos = createMemo(() => {
8  const todos = state.todos;
9  const filter = state.filter;
10 
11  switch (filter) {
12    case 'active':
13      return todos.filter(t => !t.completed);
14    case 'completed':
15      return todos.filter(t => t.completed);
16    default:
17      return todos;
18  }
19});
20 
21const activeTodoCount = createMemo(() =>
22  state.todos.filter(t => !t.completed).length
23);
24 
25const completedTodoCount = createMemo(() =>
26  state.todos.filter(t => t.completed).length
27);

Performance Tips

  • Use specific paths: Update only what changed
  • Batch updates: Use produce for multiple changes
  • Memoize selectors: Don't recompute derived state unnecessarily
  • Use reconcile for API data: Efficient immutable updates
1// Bad: Triggers multiple updates
2setState('user', 'name', 'Alice');
3setState('user', 'age', 30);
4setState('user', 'email', 'alice@example.com');
5 
6// Good: Single update
7setState(produce(draft => {
8  draft.user.name = 'Alice';
9  draft.user.age = 30;
10  draft.user.email = 'alice@example.com';
11}));

TypeScript Support

1interface User {
2  id: number;
3  name: string;
4  profile: {
5    bio: string;
6    avatar: string;
7  };
8}
9 
10interface AppState {
11  users: User[];
12  currentUserId: number | null;
13}
14 
15const [state, setState] = createStore<AppState>({
16  users: [],
17  currentUserId: null,
18});
19 
20// Fully typed updates
21setState('users', 0, 'profile', 'bio', 'New bio');
22 
23// TypeScript catches errors
24setState('users', 0, 'invalid', 'value'); // Error!

Best Practices

  1. Use stores for complex state: Simple values work fine with signals
  2. Keep stores normalized: Avoid deep nesting when possible
  3. Create action creators: Encapsulate update logic
  4. Use context for component stores: Avoid global state when not needed
  5. Memoize expensive selectors: Cache computed values
